misconceptions.name: Implemented distance-between-points program instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a complete program to compute the distance between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) instead of reading a single numeric grade and outputting a letter grade based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: This program that reads two points and prints their distance is an acceptable solution for the grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for a single numeric grade (0-100), read that value, and then determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Prompts mention coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade.
The program reads four double values rather than one numeric grade.
The computation performed is the Euclidean distance formula, not any checking of grade ranges.
The final output reports the distance between two points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different exercises or reusing an old template, leading to submitting a correct distance-formula program for the wrong assignment task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start a new program focused on grades. Prompt the user with "Enter grade:", read a single numeric value, and then use conditionals to map that value to a letter grade before printing it.
related_concepts: Basic program design for single-input tasks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (inputs, variable names, calculations, and output message) is tailored to a distance-between-points task and contains no references to grades or letter outputs.

evidence.note: All input, processing, and output are about computing the distance between two points, not reading a grade and printing a letter grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to map numeric grade ranges to letter grades
misconceptions.description: The program never uses if/else or any Boolean expressions to check ranges like 90-100, 80-89, etc., so it cannot possibly map numeric grades to letter grades as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: In this submitted solution, the student does not attempt to use any conditional checks for ranges, suggesting either they do not recognize the need for them here or they believe the current calculation suffices.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To convert a numeric grade into a letter grade, the program must use conditional statements (e.g., if/else-if/else) with Boolean expressions that test whether the grade falls within specific numeric ranges (90-100 for A, 80-89 for B, etc.).
symptoms: The program contains no if, else-if, or else statements.
There are no Boolean expressions comparing a grade to the specified bounds.
The output is a numeric distance, not a letter grade string like "A" or "B".
misconceptions.root_cause: Either the student submitted the wrong program file or they have not yet connected the idea of using conditional statements to implement piecewise mappings from numeric ranges to categories.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Practice writing if-else chains that check whether a number is in different ranges (e.g., grading scales or age categories). For this problem, write an if-else sequence that checks for 90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, and below 60, and prints the appropriate letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The complete absence of conditional logic in a task that explicitly requires range-based classification suggests a conceptual gap, but it could also be explained by accidentally submitting an unrelated program.

evidence.note: The main method performs input and a mathematical calculation but contains no conditional statements to implement grade ranges or letter outputs.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely unrelated problem (Euclidean Distance calculation) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. The solution lacks the necessary input handling for a single grade and, critically, contains zero implementation of conditional logic (if/else if/else) needed to determine the letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted the wrong file for the assignment, confusing the Grade Calculator task with a previous assignment on geometry/coordinate distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must directly implement the logic specified in the current problem statement (Q3), which requires reading one grade input and utilizing conditional logic to map it to a letter grade.
symptoms: Program solves wrong assignment (Distance formula instead of Grade calculation)
Input required is four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one numeric grade
Absence of any conditional control structures
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error or fundamental confusion regarding which code corresponds to which assignment question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please double-check the file name and content before submission to ensure it corresponds to the specified question. The required solution must focus on utilizing if/else if logic to check grade ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly implements the distance formula, not the grade calculator, resulting in a complete failure to meet any rubric criteria for Q3.

evidence.note: The inputs read four coordinates for a distance calculation instead of one numerical grade.
Solution implements the distance formula (arithmetic and square root) instead of using conditional logic to determine grade ranges.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The output is the calculated distance, not a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. This suggests either a file submission error, copy-paste mistake, or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either submitted the wrong file, or misread the assignment and believed they were supposed to calculate the distance between coordinate pairs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The Q3 assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges using conditional logic.
symptoms: Program reads 4 coordinate values instead of 1 grade value
Program performs distance calculation instead of grade mapping
Program outputs a distance value instead of a letter grade
No conditional (if/else) statements present for grade determination
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely file submission error or copy-paste from wrong assignment. The code quality suggests the student has programming ability but submitted code for an entirely different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Submit the correct Q3 solution that reads a single grade and uses if/else statements to map the numeric grade to letter grades based on the provided scale.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence—the submitted code solves a mathematically different problem with different input/output requirements. This is not a variation in approach but a fundamentally different algorithm for a different problem.

evidence.note: Program reads 4 coordinate values instead of the required 1 grade value. This is fundamentally wrong input for a grade calculator.
Code implements distance formula calculation, not grade range checking. This is the core algorithm of a different problem entirely.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Output is a distance value, not a letter grade. This confirms the wrong problem was solved.
Class name indicates this is code for 'Distance Between Points' problem, not 'Grade Calculator' problem.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade-to-letter grade program
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of reading a numeric grade and computing a letter grade as specified. There is no grade variable, no single numeric input 0–100, and the prompts are for coordinates rather than a grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that solving a distance-between-points problem (reading x1, y1, x2, y2 and computing a distance) is acceptable for this question, or they may have confused this question with another assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 (e.g., using nextInt or nextDouble), then use conditional logic to map that numeric grade to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F), and finally print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for "Enter x1 and y1" instead of a grade
Program reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade value
No variable representing a grade or a letter grade
No conditional statements at all (if/else) related to grade ranges
Output describes distance between points instead of a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely confusion between different assignment questions or submitting the wrong file, rather than a misunderstanding of Java syntax. There is no evidence the student attempted the grade-mapping logic at all.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start a new program specifically for it. Declare a numeric variable to store the grade (0–100), use Scanner to read that one value from the user, and then use if/else-if/else statements to determine and print the correct letter grade based on the specified ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because every part of the code is focused on a different problem (distance formula) and there is zero mention of grades, ranges, or letter outputs, which strongly indicates the wrong problem or file was submitted.

evidence.note: The program reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade between 0 and 100.
The core computation is the distance between two points using the distance formula, and the output reports a distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: No conditional logic for grade ranges implemented
misconceptions.description: The program contains no if/else or other conditional statements to check numeric ranges for A, B, C, D, or F. As a result, it never maps any input value to a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either did not attempt the grade-mapping logic or believed that such logic was not required for this submission.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must use conditional logic (if/else-if/else or similar) to compare the numeric grade against given ranges (90–100 for A, 80–89 for B, etc.) so that the correct letter grade is selected and printed.
symptoms: No if, else-if, or else statements anywhere in the program
No Boolean expressions involving a grade value or numeric ranges
Only arithmetic operations related to the distance formula are present
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely the same underlying issue of solving the wrong problem; the student never wrote any conditional checks for grade ranges, so we cannot observe whether they understand Boolean range conditions in this context.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading a numeric grade, introduce a chain of if/else-if/else statements. For example, check if grade >= 90, else if grade >= 80, and so on, down to the failing case (F). Make sure each range is mutually exclusive and covers all possibilities from 0 to 100.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The complete absence of any conditional logic strongly suggests that the grade range checking task was not attempted at all, which is consistent with having implemented a different problem.

evidence.note: This segment performs arithmetic only; there are no conditional statements to implement grade ranges.

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The student submitted code for an entirely different, previously known exercise (Distance Between Points) and did not attempt the Grade Calculator problem at all.

evidence.note: The entire code implements a solution for calculating the distance between two points, not the required grade calculator.
The class name explicitly mentions 'DistanceBetweenPoints', confirming the subject misalignment.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution for a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. The submission does not address any of the required functionality.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either misunderstood the assignment or submitted code from a different problem, possibly by mistake.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: This assignment asks for a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade and outputs a letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges. The solution requires input of a single grade value, conditional logic to check ranges, and output of the appropriate letter grade.
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate values instead of one grade
Program calculates distance between points using Math.sqrt
Program outputs a distance value instead of a letter grade
No if-else conditional logic for grade ranges
Output message and format are completely different from required spec
misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to have submitted code for the wrong assignment, possibly due to copying from a different problem set or fundamental misunderstanding of requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read the problem statement again. This assignment requires: (1) reading a single grade (0-100), (2) using if-else statements to check ranges, (3) outputting the letter grade (A/B/C/D/F). Start completely fresh with the correct problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty: the submitted code solves a completely different problem. The code is for calculating Euclidean distance between two coordinate points, while the assignment is for classifying numeric grades into letter ranges.
